Controls - The buttons work pretty well.  I wish the center media button was a little more pronounced as I sometimes hit the volume up or down buttons when I mean to do something else.  The B&W PX7's and AirPods Max have the better pushbutton controls (love the Max crown), while the Sony X4 and Bose NC 700 use more of the touch controls (this can be good and bad). Transparency Mode - This works really well, though I wish it automatically reduced the audio volume slightly if you have it set to continue playing.  You can also set it up in the app to mute the music when you put it into transparency mode, but for some reason it does not pause the music like the MTW2 earbuds do.  So you put it into transparency mode, have a conversation, come back to the music and a new song may be playing.  Not a big deal but a little annoying.  AirPods Max still takes the cake for transparency mode.  Sony XM4 ambient mode works well, but it always seems to lose my setting every so often and I have to go into the app and adjust.  The Bose NC 700 is really nice with adjustable noise canceling as well as going all the way to transparency mode. Battery - Battery life is not great, but sufficient for my use.  I feel like battery life should be at least 20 hours these days, with ANC on.  Bose NC 700 and AirPods Max hit it right on. Sony and B&W PX7 blow past it.  My use with these headphones tends to be a few hours at a time and mostly in my house, so it is not an issue.  However, I certainly hope that the Momentum 4's address this issue whenever they come out. Connections - Pairing between two devices is easy, reliable and it will switch between the sources very quickly. App - The app is just ok.  It always seems to take a couple tries to connect when I open it.  Sony is more reliable.  Bose is even more reliable and faster.  I do like the EQ and being able to tweak the sound, though I do tend to listen in Neutral.  You can also change noise canceling levels between Max, Anti-Wind and Anti-Pressure.  My biggest complaint about this is that I have to go into the app to do it. You can turn off the noise canceling by pushing a button on the headphones, but you cannot switch between modes without opening the app. Call quality - I am told that call quality is pretty good.  People can understand me clearly and I can hear them very well.  Better than the Sony XM4.  Much better than the B&W PX7.  Not as good as the Bose NC 700 or the AirPods Max (and Airpods Pro for that matter) As I said, the Momentum 3's do all of the above very well, but there is usually one other headset that can do it better (though not always the same one).  What does it do best?  Sound.  These things sound awesome!  I know this is very subjective, but to me, the sound stage is wide, I can hear everything crisply and clearly, and the bass is noticeable but not overwhelming.  I am not an audiophile, but I do really enjoy these.

So, you might be like me. You might see these and think - Hey, I love my Sennheiser 58x, 6xx, 800etc etc, so why not get that nice Sennheiser sound in some ANC cans? Reviews seem fairly positive. Let's try 'em. I turned on my typical test tracks and was assaulted by a molasses flood of boomy, blooming, soggy bass. It was like listening to music underwater, with the volume turned to 11. And I'm a bass-head. I own several headphones famous for bass, and I bass boost them. No, this is something different. Doesn't even sound like music. It's just an offensive mess. I set the  EQ to -5 bass (maximum) and it made the mess quieter, but no less messy. Do you remember sitting at a stop light back in 2010 or so listening to that beat up car rattling and going wubbawubbawubbawuba all mess and no music? Well, if you're nostalgic for that, you're in luck. On to my third complaint about bass: It's small. Some headphones have an impressive high resolution "wall of sound" where you are enveloped. Not these, it's like two tiny horrible sounding subwoofers that don't even blend to the music. The mids? Not bad actually. A bit recessed. Outside of the bass bleed, they sound fairly average. And highs? A bit harsh while still being laid back. A -5,+2,+3 eq made the headphones listenable, but not good. No EQ setting could save this mess. Look - if you listen to Beats headphones and think they're wonderful, you might like these. IF you listen to literally any quality headphones (audeze, other sennheisers, etymotic, even koss) you're going to have a bad time. And the soundstage? It's weird. It's not placed correctly, and frequencies don't blend right. What about ANC? Well, it's passable. The transparency mode works OK if the music isn't playing. Usage? You have to fold them to shut them down. While I like that folding shuts them down, they need another way. I store headphones on hooks and don't want to adjust them every time. Comfort? Pretty solid, actually. But there's plenty of  comfortable cans that actually sound good. Battery life? Well, I don't know. I've tried many, many headphones. These are the only ones I straight up couldn't stand to listen to. They are /offensively bad./ What the heck, Sennheiser?

I had a pair of M2 for several years, and loved them to death. Travelled in all climates, situations, several countries, across oceans, in bed, playing games, yada yada yada. They recently broke so I ordered a new pair on Amazon alongside the newer M3, so I have been A/Bing these for several hours, with all types of music, from Bob Dylan to Hiatus Kaiyote, Black Thought to Rage Against the Machine. They both trade blows in different types of music. I feel like metal, hard rock, and faster genres favor the M2. When I listened to "Killing In The Name" by Rage Against The Machine, the mids on the M3 felt distant and recessed, almost veiled, whereas the M2 is right in your face and the decay on the instruments is much quicker. Zach's ferocious vocals are much more impactful on the M2, whereas on the M3 they feel like he's further away and the band drowns him out....not what I want for a band like Rage. In hip-hop, like Skepta's "No Sleep" the bass feels a bit overly boosted and bloated. It's punchy, but it does sound artificially inflated, whereas with the M2, it's much more neutral and presents the entire spectrum more evenly. I haven't really done much with Sennheiser's EQ in their app, because I never EQ my headphones, but it may be worth a try to even them out a bit. In male and female vocals, both headphones have similarly milky smooth and luscious presentations. In Fiona Apple's "I Want You to Love Me" the M3 really shine with the piano in the foreground, while keeping her vocals up close and personal. However, the boosted sub bass can make the strings sound a bit too bloated for my taste. Whereas with the M2, her beautiful vocals are clearer and not muddied by the bloated sub bass. The piano keys are sharper, crisper, and more sparkly. But once the drums come in, the M3 wins. The impact from the larger drivers, you can feel in your bones, it's visceral. The drums on the M2 are just in your head. All in all, it has been an extremely tough decision for me. $355 for the M3 (tax included) and about $185 for the replacement M2. Both are excellent headphones in their own right. The lower battery life of the M3 may cause issues, however I have not had the chance to test that. The one feature I care about is the fact that music pauses on the M3 when they are taken off your head. The M3 seem to have more of a wow factor at times, whereas the M2 are a solid all arounder that is more neutral and will not satiate the modern basshead. If you love visceral bass, you need to choose the M3. I wish Sennheiser kept the physical styling of the M2, because the plastic cups and band style I think are hideous on the M3. They just feel like they won't hold up to the rigors of travel. I stuffed my M2 deep into some very tightly packed bags, tossed them around, wore them in the snow, among many other situations, and they tanked everything. I don't know if I will be able to do the same with the M3. They feel like more of a competitor to the yuppie Bose offerings, which is not something I like. EDIT: Ended up returning them and will keep the M2 for now. The fact that auto pause is triggered by slightly tilting your head to the right with the M3 is a HUGE deal breaker. They sound great, but not great enough to get past that annoying feature.

Currently I own a pair of Sennheiser HD 600 (wired), open ear state of the art headphones. These closed ear Momentum 3's are darn close and without the wires. After playing an SACD, the sound truly kicked in despite Bluetooth compression (nothing beats wired).  Quite satisfied. Super comfortable. You can walk around the house and not realize they are on. They easily paired with my LG Stylo 2 as well as a high end windows PC and WIndows Tablet, etc. The user interface is quite simple just don't use the finger slide EQ, there's an option to toggle this Off for actual sliders. You can save presets as well. In case you're wondering, the hard wired 2.5-3.5mm cable is for those that don't have BlueTooth such a an old Ipod.  3 Modes for power: Overhead is "On", collapsed around your neck is Standby and folder is Off unlike the Bose NC 700 where you have to find that little tiny power button. Only downsides I can find are the Noise Cancellation, its fair - not great not bad (Bose wins here) and also the pairing of only 2 Devices, Bose NC 700 wins here as well, they can do 8. The case is a soft shell vs. Bose clam hard shell. I can live with all of those. Upside: Powering options as above, comfort supreme, lightweight (1.4 ounces heavier than Bose - barely noticeable difference we tested both), good support team, high quality hardware, 8.5 to 9 out of 10 rating.

Consistent dropouts from bluetooth connection when sitting in front of television approx. 12 feet away. No discernible reason.  Dropouts while listening to music as well if I turn my head or move in the "wrong" direction. Very disappointed in bluetooth inconsistency because this is a pricey pair of cans. I usually end up using my Bose on-ear wireless for television watching. A shame, and I am contemplating selling the Momentums since I bought them for their wireless capability.  BUT, to give credit where it's due:  the sound quality is pure Sennheiser and I notice no difference in the sound quality from my wired Senns (58x Jubilees), in fact, the Momentum 3's may be a tad richer. Your call.

The instrument separation is really good. Sound stage feels nice and wide. People coming from DJ and consumer and entry level headphones will be pleased. Sound signature: Bass - boomy and physical thanks to the large earcups and drivers. It's well contained and tight so it doesn't fizzle out like "muddy" base. Mids - they're not unclear but don't stand out like the bass and highs. Vocal listeners should look away from these headphones. Highs - detailed and clear. They don't feel veiled or noisy. Comfort: The earcups are some magic memory foam gentler than any pillow I've slept on. The headband's clamping force is about right for a larger/wider head. Maybe unnoticeable on slimmer/smaller heads. The headband's foam is a bit too firm I'd prefer if they were as soft as the earcups. Buttons work well and their only fault is the rubbery and flimsy feel because of being made of rubber.

Very happy with my Sennheiser Momentum 3!  Next to the Bowers & Wilkins PX7, it's the best sounding headphones I have ever heard!  Very close to my PX7 for detail and soundstage!  Better audio quality than Sony and Bose!  The bass thumps and the highs are so clear!  My PX7 and Momentum 3 are my two favorite headphones!  I have the Bose 700, Sony WH-1000XM3, Bose QC35II, Bose Soundlink II, and Sony WH-XB900N.  Bowers & Wilkins PX7 and Sennheiser Momentum 3 sounds better than all the rest!

For the last 3 month I've been looking for noise cancelling over-ear headphones for myself. Now, when I've made my choice, I'm going to give you a detailed comparison between headphones I'd tried before I made my decision. This review is going to be quite detailed, not one of those short ones. First of all, I had my own criteria that are somewhat personal. Because of those I did not consider any Sony headphones due to their known "feature" of an always enabled transparency mode during calls, which is ridiculous, and Bowers &Wilkins PX7 and Shure Aonic 50 due to their unattractive design (very personal thing). Here's a list of my criteria and conclusions about headphones I've tried: 1.Comfortable fit. -Sennheiser PXC 550-II is a winner. They are very comfortable and offer enough adjustment options to have a best fit and cause no discomfort for hours. -Bose NC 700 have somewhat tight fit, but other than that are also very comfortable, no problems wearing them for hours as well. -Bose QC 35-II are OK, but I it takes some time to get used to their fit, cushions could be better for sure. -Soundcore Q30 would be very nice option for using them for hours, but they have such a small amount of padding material that your ears are touching inner part of earcups, very unpleasant experience. - Momentum 3 are VERY heavy, they weight around 0.6 kg and you really feel that! For me they've caused almost an instant headache. That was the main reason why I returned them. 2.High Sound Quality. - Sennheiser Momentum 3 have the best sound on my opinion. Plenty of bass, I did really enjoy listening music with those. - Bose NC 700 sound great as well. I'd say that the sound is more balanced, but I'm not an audio expert and that is just my impression. - Soundcore Q30 are surprisingly good in terms of sound  for the lowest price here. Plus their app has tons of EQ presets, which is not the case with other brands. - Sennheiser PXC 550-II sound quality is good, but nothing impressive, just as no major flaws there. - Bose QC 35-II sound just OK, noticeably worse than PXC 550-II on my opinion. 3.High call quality. - Bose NC 700 should offer the best call quality here. You can adjust sidetone during calls, which is great. Hven't had to many calls with them, but so far so good. - Sennheiser PXC 550-II is definitely a way to go if you need a headset for taking calls. No complaints from people I was talking to, the only downside is that sidetone can be adjusted if a quite odd method using PC and USB connection. - Soundcore Q30 are OK for calls, didn't get an complaints when used them for calls. Sidetone can be turned on/off on the go. - Sennheiser Momentum 3 is OK for calls, had some complaints about robotic sound when used them though. Sidetone can be turned on/off during calls, very convenient. - Bose QC 35-II are the worst on the list. Sidetone is always on and cannot be turned off during calls, good luck trying to use them for a call when you have some serious noise on the background. You can find people complaining about this "feature" on a Bose forum for YEARS, but nothing happens. Non of adds or item descriptions mention that, look for something else if you are planning to take calls with headphones on. 4. Noise cancelling features and etc. - Bose NC 700 are way far ahead, no other headphones out of those I've tired are even close. Just perfect. - Sennheiser Momentum 3 are quite good. ANC is decent (but nothing close to Bose NC 700), very convenient to switch between ANC types, transparency is implemented well. - Bose QC 35-II offer great ANC, better than Momentum 3, but no transparency when you need it (better to have it always on for calls, right?). - Soundcore Q30 have the most user-friendly system of ANC controls (transport-outdoor-indoor) out there, but NC by itself is not that great, it works but could be better. - PXC 550-II really suck when it comes to noise cancelling. They feature Adaptive ANC, but the reality is that it is very abrupt, can just turn off for a second and turn back on instantly. I haven't noticed any gradual changes for ANC level when used. ANC controls is a different criteria, but it's so horrible that it affect everything. Even if you just leave it on it may turn off for a second at any time. Transparency mode when not a a call is good thou. 5.Battery life & efficient wired mode. - Soundcore Q30 are miles ahead. They really do last for 40 hours when ANC is on, full charge  via USB-C takes only 2 hours. They also can be used for passive playback via 3.5 cable when turned off, super convenient. - Bose NC 700 have way smaller battery life (20 hrs), but also use USB-C, full charge takes 2.5 hours, can be used with a passive payback via 2.5 to 3.5 cable while turned off. - Bose QC 35-II are pretty similar with Bose NC 700 when it comes to battery, but they use micro-USB, which is less convenient. - Momentum 3 's battery lasts only 17 hours and takes 3 hours for full charge, even thou it also uses USB-C. Cannot be used for passive payback because they are turning on automatically when you unfold them, but if you use included 2.5 to 3.5 cable they turn to some power-saving mode and can be used for longer (I'd used them for 5 hours while they were on 20% charge and they still haven't died). - While PXC-550-II  are advertised to have 30-hour battery life and fully charge within 3 hours, with ANC on they barely last 20 hours and a full charge takes 4 hours ( charge to 80% takes less around 1.5 hours though). But the biggest problem is when you are using them with a wire there is no noticeable change, they don't have any smart mode, even if you turn Bluetooth off (that is the only power-saving feature available) they won't last longer. 6.Ease of use & Controls - Bose NC 700 have a perfect balance between button and touch control, touch controls are very responsive, easy to switch between ANC modes. - Bose QC 35-II feature convenient button controls, you also can switch between connected devices with on/off button. - Sennheiser Momentum 3 have great button controls, really easy to control ANC and transparency modes. But no power button, which is frustrating -Soundcore Q30 button controls are quite well made, can be turned off with a button, transparency mode is easy to use also. The only flaw is that a transparency mode doesn't stop the music playing, which kind of defeats the purpose of that feature. - PXC 500-II touch controls aren't as responsive as Bose NC 700's , still good nonetheless. But ANC control is clearly a nightmare! There is a tiny-tine knob that switches ANC from Max to user mode or to turn it off, but  it's almost impossible to operate it properly on the go. Worst decision ever made by headphone designers. 7. Look & feel -Clearly Sennheiser Momentum 3 have the most unique look and premium feel. Somewhat personal, but their design is truly a step aside from any standard builds. - Bose NC 700 are very minimalistic, and clearly have a premium feel. Look great as well. - Sennheiser PXC 550-II do make a nice impression and definitely don't look cheap. Their earcups also look like horse hoofs, which I personally find amusing. - Bose QC 35-II really look like average headphones, not as much for the price range they fall in (200-300$). No major complaints thou. - Soundcore Q30's look and feel reminds you about their low price as much as they can. Cheap plastic on earcups and loud clicking buttons, lack of padding material in cushions-- "you get what you've paid for", as people say. Only the headband looks and feels nice. They could go with more minimalistic approach for the earcups, but they didn't. Bought them only because I the company makes really good earbuds that I absolutely love. Button line -- which one worth the money payed? - No wonder that Soundcore Q30 is a steal. Just the fact that 80$ headphones can compete with 200-400$ rivals says a lot. If you are on the budget and OK with cons I've listed -- that is no-brainer here. - I'd say that Bose NC 700 are too expensive for everyday headphones (hello AirPods Max!), but only they will give you all the feature implemented well and working great without any sacrifices. Sadly but I haven't found any cheaper option that fulfills by needs, even though I would be OK with not as good NC and maybe more standard look & feel. That is why I chose Bose NC 700. - While it has some serious issues, Sennheiser PXC 550-II is also a decent choice if you don't want to break the bank for a pair of headphones. Very comfy and nice looking, I'd stick with those if they had a power button and more stable ANC. - Sennheiser Momentum 3 is a great option even for 300$ price if you are OK with wearing such bulky & heavy headphones for hours. Otherwise it's just a no go. - Finally, I do thing that Bose QC  35-II is the worst decision here and would only work if you need headphones for noise cancelling during flights. The lowest price I saw was 200$ and for those money PXC 500-II is a way better choice. P.S.: attached is a phono of Soundcore Q30, Bose NC 700 and Sennheiser  PXC 550-II from left to right. I've already returned Bose QC 35-II and Sennheiser Momentum 3 because they were no go for me.

Everyone has different criteria for headphones.  Mine were: must be reasonably comfortable for extended wear; must have excellent sound quality for music; must be intuitive and easy to use for work conference calls.  And obviously, Bluetooth pairing had to work smoothly. In other words, I like to listen to music while working but occasionally have to take a call. I read a lot of reviews before buying these and find that the reviewers got it right.  They are easy to use, sound great, and have sort of OK noise cancellation.  I have used Bose noise cancelling phones in the past and those are on a whole different level - the noise cancellation is so effective that it's almost eerie.  As many others have said, the Sennheiser noise cancellation does best with droning sounds such as HVAC. So overall, if your criteria are similar to mine, you'll be happy.  Before I started using these I was using a pair of old Oppo phones which originally sold for $700 (but had no microphone or Bluetooth) so I am used to pretty good sound.  I do not feel deprived listening to these.

These headphones are solidly built with premium materials, including super soft, leather wrapped ear pads, firm but not overbearing metal head clamp. They are very comfortable on your head and ears, you can use them for hours on end without discomfort or overheating. But most importantly: the sound quality is exceptional. You can hear every instrument crisp and clear around you like you are in the middle of the band; electronic music sound fenomenal with lows, mids and highs coming through perfectly uncluttered, dynamic, powerful, no distortion or muffleing. Just fantastic! It is possible to equalize their sound using the app, once you change the equalizer profile it stays on that profile regardless of app connectivity The cable to listen wired could be standard rather than a proprietary Sennheiser design, and I wish you could simply cover an earphone to pause, but the buttons are simple and intuitive. Also, I found that noise cancelling is not bad but could be better, however, the majestic sounds makes up for it by far, imo.

For listeners who care more about sound quality than isolation, these headphones are a must. I upgraded to these from the Sennheiser HD 380 Pro, and I am very happy with them. The attention to detail in the construction and tuning stand out, while the isolation is more focused on enhancing audio quality than it is supreme isolation from all outside noise. The first test drive with these was on a four hour flight. I wore them straight through and had no ear fatigue or discomfort from excess pressure. The ear cups and head band are very soft and comfortable! The talk-through feature allowed me to hold full conversations with my wife and airline stewards without missing anything. Would recommend for someone who is on the go and cares more about a flat response and punchy bass than someone who wants a higher end noise canceling headphone.

These are incredible headphones. The only downside is that the bluetooth connection can clip if you wave a body part (arm) between the phone and the headphones when the phone is in a pocket. If that's a huge issue for you keep them in the wired configuration because Sennheiser really created an incredible product with these cans. I came across the very first Momentum headphones in an airport having two hours of time to spend. Being an audiophile I ended up in a store that had every major manufacturers over-ear noise cancelling headphones. This was many years before covid and you could try them out. I went through several of the biggest names and the fourth one was Sennheiser Momentum (they were the initial version). I was blown away by the sound quality and balance. I then looked at the price tag and rationalized that I didn't want to spend that amount on something that was only for my own enjoyment. That experience stuck with me for 4 or 5 years of still wanting them. I finally purchased them and they're even better than the first time. I've tried pushing their limits with every type of music/movie/podcast/content that I can. They are a truly amazing product. This is the first product I've ever given a 5 star review for. My only regret is I didn't bring this audio quality into my life earlier.

I've bought the 3 usual suspects: Sony xxxxM4, Bose xxx700, and this guy. returned 2, and kept the Sennheiser. I also have a Sennheiser HD1, momentum 3 improved on the sound stage and separation. So, Sony is superior for ANC, Bose is superior for call quality. I buy headphones for 1 thing and 1 thing only: sound quality. I've tested every music I like: Classical, Jazz, Rap, Folk, Rock..in every category this Sennheiser killed the other 2 easily. Listening Adele at the Royal Albert Hall made me feel like I am in the front row. Nils Lofgren's I'll Arise, I felt the vibration of his guitar strings. But of course your music has to be at least 16-bit / 44.1 kHz to really enjoy this baby.

I wanted a nice pair of noise cancelling bluetooth headphones that still had a wired option to use without battery via a standard audio jack. Reading about the Momentum 3's had me hopeful they would perfectly fit my needs and they technically do all that but not very well. The noise cancellation on these is not very good at all. You can tell the difference with it on versus off, but just barely. I'm quite happy with the sound quality over both bluetooth and wired. I'm still a bit disappointed in the audio quality though considering the cost for these. The build quality of the headphones themselves are acceptable but the included cable for wired use is terribly cheap, way too short at just over 4 feet and super inconvenient with the smaller 2.5mm twist in jack. I accidentally tugged the cable just slightly and the 2.5mm plug started separating. CHEAP!

Basing this review off headphones I have to compare it with as a casual headphone user, I have the QC25 and Sony WH-1000XM3. Listening to music on Spotify. Sound: Sennheiser takes the win in the sound quality category for sure, when testing side by side along the other two, it provides a much more immersive experience and clearer bass than the other two. Comfort:I would rank the Sennheiser momentum 3 comfort to be under the QC25 and above the Sony. Sennheiser is a bit heavier compared to the other two, but at the same time the plush padding makes up for it, but still the Bose is more comfortable to wear for long duration. Noise isolation: Sennheiser ranks last in terms of noise cancellation, but this does not really affect me too much as my room is fairly quiet already and I don't take these headphone out too often. but if Noise isolation is something you need to have, i would go with the Sony as a better over all pick. Connection: I havent had any issue with the sennheiser, but i do notice the wireless connection on the Sony is a stronger and more stable at longer range. I personally like the physical buttons on the Sennheiser vs the Sony, as it gives instant feed back where as touch control can activate the wrong button. Software wise I would have to give it to the Sony as the Sony has much more option and adjustment available also comes with many preset EQ.

My review after two months of weekly usage! Cons: Bluetooth implementation seems flawed and noice cancellation is just okay. Comparing to my other wireless active noise cancelling headsets that I've tried such as the Beyerdynamic Lagoon ANC, a couple Jabras, and the Sony XM3, my Momentum 3 unit has a noticeably raised noise floor. Thankfully I do not hear any noise during actual playback. But for sure during gaps between songs / videos, I can hear a high pitched hum, or varying pops/clicks. I only ever really noticed it in a quiet home environment vs commuting on the train. Also, there is just noticeable audio-video desync when paired with my Apple iphone or iPad, which I have never experienced with any other wireless headphones. As for the noise cancellation, it was just an added bonus for me but when I am looking for it, it could stand to be stronger or support varying toggleable levels. Battery life is average. I've been able to get through hours long Zoom calls on the Lagoon but the Sennheiser starts to run low under similar conditions. I think the battery readout is also too vague. "More than 40% battery left" - Does that mean 59%, or 41%? The hinge on/off mechanic is gimmicky and can actually be painful! Literally on day 2 of ownership I was a little careless and gave myself a nasty pinch on the webbing between my left thumb and forefinger. There is also the concern that when "off" (hold the multifunction button while opening the hinge and the voice tells you Power Off), that it is actually still passively draining the battery. The Beyer with its physical on/off switch instills more confidence. Unlike the Beyerdynamic Lagoon ANC, one cannot turn it on and simultaneously use the 3.5mm jack. I want to take advantage of active noice cancelling while still opting for the better sound quality by going wired, but in my tests the sound output level is extremely low and dead sounding when trying to do both at the same time. I was worried I was somehow going to break something so I stopped trying. Pros: Comfort is very good. I usually prefer headphones with larger drivers as the cups/pads tend to be larger too. I do not experience temple or jaw fatigue w headphones (so far), but rather ear-clamp fatigue. I returned the Momentum 2 because the pinch was just too distracting. The M3 cups feel more plush and overall have more surface area contacting the head so less of a gripping sensation on the actual ears. Overall build quality is pretty solid. Less creaky compared to the Beyerdynamic Lagoon. Minimal microphonics with the included 3.5mm cable. Sound is great. For a closed-back headphone targeting the market for mobility + intimacy, the bass has plenty of body but is not overpoweringly rumbling, which is my preference. I found the instrument separation to be excellent and on par with some of the more expensive audiophile grade headphones I've demoed. The Transparent Hearing feature opens up the soundstage even more, even though there is some trickery involved there. I feel like no frequencies in the mix are getting lost here. If I had to nitpick, on more vocal forward genres such as Hip-Hop I found certain voices a tad shouty, or certain piano tones a little sharp. I am more attuned to V-shaped profiles so take with a grain of salt. Attenuating the 1k-2k range with EQ fixed it for me. Overall, a fine, comfortable headphone for casual listening with the added convenience of decent enough wireless capability, but definitely with its quirks.

After a lot of searching I settled on these because I was looking for these requirements: - aptx LL for single player gaming and watching videos on my laptop on my nintendo switch and PC - good sound reproduction - bluetooth multi-point pairing and easy switching between devices - Good call quality - Good comfort - Decent portability - Transparent hearing I think when all these points are taken together, these headphones seem to be the best option of the ones I've seen (assuming price isn't too much of a constraint). It's not fantastic sounding (there are better sounding wireless headsets) and it doesn't have the best feature set (ldac or aptx hd or aptx adaptive would've been nice), but because it hit all the points above I'm pretty happy with it. Here are a few highs and lows: Highs - Built in equalizer that can be configured via the phone app (set it once and it's saved directly into the headphones, no matter what device you're connected to). This was a lifesaver because the bass region on these headphones are overly emphasized. Applying -3dB helped them sound a little more neutral. - Multi-point pairing is a little wonky (can be slow in connecting/disconnecting) but generally works really well - App allows easily switching between connected bluetooth devices - 3 Different levels of ANC, plus ability to turn ANC and transparent hearing off - Folds for portability - usb c charging - lightweight Lows - No track skip button on headphones, only play/pause and volume. Disappointing that volume buttons can't be used for this. - Overemphasized bass (although EQing gets it down to an acceptable level) - No aptx-hd or ldac streaming. Realistically there are probably other elements in the audio chain that are limiting this though (e.g. Spotify). - Only way to power off is to fold in headphones (no power button)

After spending many hours researching wireless headphones I finally decided to give these sennheisers a chance. They are absolutely amazing. Sound quality is exceptional, they are incredibly comfortable, and the leather on these is unbelievably soft. The noise cancelation and battery life isn't the best on the market, but are more than sufficient for my needs and it has worked well for me. If you think these will work for you and are debating getting them, just go for it, they are well worth it. Only real complaint is the travel case it comes with is not very nice, but there are lots of 3rd party cases available for not too much money. I picked up a nice hard shell case for around $10. I haven't experienced any problems with these headphones thus far, but will update my review in the future if any arise.

It's all about the sound!  That's the first thing you should be considering with any audio device.  And the Sennheiser Momentum 3s deliver.  Clear, clean, balanced and a great soundstage.  Whether it's Justin Bieber or Vivaldi's The Four Seasons, these headphones sound great.  Very comfortable, the controls are easy to use, and even though they "only" last for 17 hours before needing a charge (compared to 30 hours for some wireless headphones), that is not an issue for me.  Plug them into a USB C port and they charge right up.  I also love the way they collapse up very easily into a nice tight package when not being used.  And considering these are Sennheisers, and of such good quality, the price is very reasonable.  Highly recommended.

I’ll probably update this review over time.  It was at two stars, now down to one... maybe they’ll work their way up to two again. I have since gotten a pair of Shure Aonic 50s, which are outstanding... That’s a lotta money tied up in headphones!  I probably should’ve just bought the new Apple cans instead. In the meanwhile, I’ve exchanged dozens upon dozens of emails with Sennheiser about the myriad issues I’ve had with these.  It all began with an apparently-software and/or firmware-related problem, which developed into further problems (Note: the app is pretty jank too, and none of the updates entirely stopped it from glitching and losing connection, etc. But, it’s a requisite in order to adjust EQ or ANC, et al.). Before I could even manage to get all of the software/firmware/app nonsense worked out, a more serious hardware problem developed.  To wit: the headphones seem to believe that they are still plugged in via the (annoyingly proprietary) 3.5-2.5mm cord, which I did only a few times.  As a result, they’ll no longer let me pair with anything.  This is apparently a common problem people have “fixed” in various ways (“raking the pins,” etc.), many of which I’ve tried to no avail.  How ridiculous: a $350 gadget with a terminally faulty switch/sensor?  Please.  My old school Sony Studio Monitors last a decade, even treated more carelessly. THE CUSTOMER SERVICE DEPARTMENT SHOULD BE ASHAMED OF ITSELF.  They’re dismissive, misleading, often give incorrect information, don’t listen carefully to questions (instead generally replying with a prescribed response referring you to something that doesn’t work or isn’t even applicable); and I could go on. Just the other day I got a sarcastic reply from one of their people, who was actually supposed to have called me more than two weeks ago.  I wrote (paraphrasing): “Hello again _____, I’ve now contacted you twice since you were supposed to call me on the telephone, but have heard nothing.  Are you, or are you not, going to contact me.  Please advise.  Respectfully, ____” She replied, “You’re very welcome.”  I thought this might have been sent to me by mistake, so I followed up... she very brusquely replied that my issue would better be handled by yet another department (the 4th so far I think). The above rude transaction took place as I’m simply trying to send them in for warranty repair given the development of this issue that is clearly a hardware problem.  To be clear, I treat all my A/V gear like it’s made of antique glass (Another note: the case these come with is a joke; if you do buy them, get an actual hard case to protect your investment.). Trying to send them in has even become a rigamarole.  I’m almost 2 months into that fiasco now, having sent proof of purchase, serial number, their form, etc. I don’t  even have specific instructions or a shipping box yet.  By the way, it appears they expect YOU to pay for the shipping to get their bunk product repaired, in England, I believe.  Another slap in the face.  This may explain part of my delays here as I flat out refused to do that.  But, at this rate, they’ll be out of warranty before I have even sent them off... and I imagine it will take months in turnaround time too. I realize this review is darn salty; but generally, I try to be very convivial with folks.  Sugar works better than vinegar and all that.  This has worn me down though. If you don’t have the patience for this type of thing, don’t buy these.  As others have commented, the sound quality is exceptional.  Virtually everything else is a train wreck.  What a shame.  Sennheiser has always been so top notch in my experience.  Perhaps they’re better off sticking with the old-school tech.

The headphones randomly pause/mute uncontrollably about every 5 - 10 seconds. I believe it has something to do with the auto pause/mute but after turning off the feature in the app it continued. After I had to register the headphones, create an account and provide all proof of purchase info the manufacturer wanted me to pay for shipping for the return. Next time I will buy these types of things at brick and mortar stores where I can easily swap them for a functioning set. Update: The replacement headphone set also does not work.

...and I've had a lot. As a music maker/producer, my headphones are my lifeline. My preference is towards Sennheiser's and AKG's EQ curve, comfort, isolation, build. These are in a league of their own. First off, the sound is outstanding: very wide, detailed stereo field, good bass presence, but what feels like a neutral EQ. They're great for reference monitors and accurate enough that I can mix with them. And for critical listening or just plain enjoying music, they put a smile on my face! And with the app, you can program your own EQ profiles. Comfort: they're not light, but have leather ear cups and a tight seal so you can comfortably wear them for hours, with no ear fatigue. The sound isolation is exemplary and also has a transparency mode. Best feature: they're full-size headphones, but fold neatly: on/off is controlled by folding/unfolding them. Battery life is great and the Bluetooth is dependable. Quality: they're incredibly-well built for comfort and durability. I feel they'll last for many years. Cons: tiny bit glitchy when it comes to calling. Moving your head can automatically cause them to mute and unmute. To troubleshoot, you just have to wait 3-5 seconds after you power them up until you put them on (must be something to do with the noise-canceling feature). All in all, outstanding in every way. They sound incredible, look incredible, and are built to last. Buy em!

I wish I were writing a 5 star review, as I would be if my model were up to par with what I assume to be the normal product. It is the best headphone for sound quality at this range and I've tried just about all of them. Soundstage is grander than the WH1000xm3, PX, M2, and MDR1A all duct taped together. Bass is powerful yet tight, mids are clear, treble is detailed. Vocals are thick and pronounced even with the massive soundstage. I don't understand how they've done that. However - Battery life and noise cancellation are second rate to NC700/WH1000xm3/PX7. *My (Only) complaint* My model has a hissing noise in the top left driver on songs that feature long bass notes. It's un-ignorable. If you wish to test if yours has it, look up "bass test hz" on youtube and click the black and green video. It's safe and non-boosted. If you have a defective model, the hiss will be unmistakable. Can't give this product 5 stars because it is a major hindrance on some of my favorite songs. Also can't give it 3 because it's only noticeable on a minority of songs.

While perhaps not the most precise reproduction of every frequency, the soundstage created by these is amazing. coupled with the noise cancellation, I find I can close my eyes and just experience the music. I have periodic Bluetooth connection issues, but it may be my iPhone with too many Bluetooth items. A toggling of Bluetooth on my phone fixes it. Lastly, the auto-pause is pretty good. It’s not perfect, but if you wait the 5s to let it calibrate it’s great. If it’s a problem, you can use the app to turn it off. Overall I recommend them without reservation over the Sony competition or any headphones in this price range.

I've tested a bunch of leading noise-cancelling, over-ear headphones in the last few months. All the top brands -- AKG, Sennheiser, Master & Dynamic, Beyerdynamic, Philips, Sony, Shure. And the Sennheiser Momentum 3 Wireless have the best sound, without question. Very good imaging, detail, soundstage. A bass-forward sound signature that can be well-tuned in the app. Very nice construction. High quality. There are a few flaws, though. These cans are heavy, so fatigue could be an issue. Also, there are some wonky connectivity issues, as the Bluetooth range and connection with the app are wonky at times. Finally, the battery life isn't as good as the competition.

I have a dozen mid range headphones like apple, bose and so on.  This Momentum 3 is now my favorite.  It’s app and simple button set up is much easier to use than my numerous other brands.  As far as sound quality, I have no idea because of 40 years of jet turbine noise.  Volume is the only valid comment I can make and it is good.  They saved space by not having and on/off switch.  I couldn’t get it off and neither could the Amazon tech until I closed it up for return.  Bang, off it went. I was very pleased not to return my now favorite headphone set.  I might be the only one who has had this problem, but maybe one other user might be helped.  The manual gets 2 stars.

The auto play/pause feature is too sensitive. It would pause my music when I turned my head. Bluetooth connectivity seems poor. Every few minutes or so I would get a small hiccup in the sound. Very annoying. The folding mechanism can PINCH THE S*** out of you! Be careful. Pretty weighty headphones, after wearing for 15 min or so it started causing discomfort on the crown of my head. You cannot use just any usb c for charging. Mac chargers wont do it. You cannot use just any aux cable either! The jack on the phones is smaller than the average one. Sound quality was pretty good but the bass was lacking I found a pair of bluetooth headphones for half the price that I like a lot more. If these were cheaper headphones I wouldn't leave such a critical review. But for $400 I expect a better functioning device.

Battery stopped charging after 1 week of use -- tried plugging in the headphones both in the open and closed state, and resetting the headphones didn't help either. When the battery still worked, the noise cancellation on these headphones was not that great -- I live in an area where there's a lot of traffic and transit noise, and these headphones were unable to block those out, where my IEMs with foam tips were able to isolate a lot better. One positive thing I can say is that the pads are soft and don't make the sides of my head too warm. If the headband were a little less hard and had a little more padding, I would feel comfortable wearing these for more than 1 hour at a time.

I'm returning my 2nd pair of these headphones because the cut out when you turn your head left, right, or up and down. Never had a headphone do this before. The 2nd pair I got from Amazon is worse than the first pair I had. These cut out for up to 15-20 at a time. The first pair i had would cut out from 3-5 seconds. Thats very annoying.  I have some Sony Mx950's and they dont do this. Bad product by Sennheiser. They sound great tho. I give them that.

I'm returning it, plain and simple. Not worth all this money. Hard wire is not a default setting, Requires sequencing of controls to get to. Starts searching for wireless devices the moment it's turned on. No choice. Not as loud as advertised. My $40 Sonys are louder and more dynamic right out of the box, no fuss. This Sennheiser Consumer Audio M3AEBTXL sound is not crisp or dynamic, too muffled. Needs too much equalizer programming applications to achieve sound quality. Also, battery verbal alert will only state battery above 80% capacity. Will not state if fully charged or at 100% no matter how long you leave it on a charger. I charged it for 3 days, same result. Really disappointed that something so expensive has to be so heavily customized and programmed by an average consumer. And then will not even charge to 100%. Lesson learned here.

I have these as well as a set of the Bose 700s. For my primary use, the audio on these is amazing, which is why I'm rating them at 4 stars. Where they fall a little short is the features. The controls could be a little better and the auto pause feature while very cool and a nice add is too sensitive and will pause your music when you yawn or otherwise shift your head sometimes. My other complaint is when these are paired to multiple devices sometimes they can be touchy with which device they take sound from. So if I'm watching TV on them an I get a text message it cuts the sound from the TV and will not reconnect until I power them down and re start them. Annoying but something that can be worked around. If you are using these for listening to TV, or HiFi music the sound on these is dramatically better than the competitors. If  You are planning to use these paired on your phone for travel etc, the Bose 700s may be a better choice.

I have bought and listened extensively to the Sony WH-1000XM4, Bose NCH 700 (wife’s) and the Bower & Wilkins PX7 and the Sennheiser Momentum 2’s AND 3’s. Without a doubt, not even close, the Sennheisers sound signature blew away all of the others! I read many reviews comparing the Bose and Sony’s to the Sennheisers and all I can say is that Bose and Sony must be paying people to write favorable reviews for them! If you want a noise cancelling headphone that you can take calls on, then Bose and Sony make fine products for you. If you want a Bluetooth headphone that delivers awesome, warm, bassy sound that puts a smile to your face, then get the Sennheisers. Heck, the Moentum 2’s sound better than the Bose, Sony’s and B&Ws! Seriously, the Sennheisers cancel sound just fine, take phone calls clearly and turn off and on just by putting them on your head. Not only that, Sennheisers are mad of metal and real leather, not plastic and faux leather like the others. I can listen to my Sennheisers for hours, while the others would give me a headache after a few minutes. For the life of me, I don’t why more people are not buying these cans. Just. Awesome. Sound! Don’t believe the hype surrounding the Bose and Sony’s.

I am Sennheiser fan, so the review may have some bias. I have been used this headphone for 3 weeks. Overall, it is good product. pros: 1. Excellent sound. I always has no question for Sennheiser’s sound. 2. Comfort to wear. The headphones looks like a huge one, but it feels comfortable when wearing it. 3. I like physical control buttons. However, all those buttons are on your right side. However, I perfer the left. 4. Battery is good. Cons 1. Noise Cancellation. Emmmm….I don’t think Sennheiser knows how to do noise cancellation for his product. The noise cancellation is not what I expect. Sony or Bose products are doing much better. 2. This is an over-ear headphone, not works for long time wearing in the hot weather. 3. Still a little bit heavy. 4. Two weeks after I bought it, Amazon gives an 50 dollars off…(Can you hear my heart is crying? T_T) Conclusion. If you are looking for a good sound quality headphone, without high requirement for noise cancellation, for example, at work or study in the library. This is exactly the right product. But if you simply just looking for good noise cancellation headphone and do not care about the sound. I believe there will be many other choices for you.

These points are all in comparison to the Sennheiser Momentum 2 1. More expensive 2. Heavier, less comfortable (grips your ears more tightly, top band is more padded though) 3. Worse sound quality (less bass, quieter, less dynamic) 4. Worse battery life (~18hrs vs ~22) 5. Makes the last tab I had opened in Chrome start playing automatically NOT through the headphones, but through my computer speakers. While it's nice you can just unfold the headphones to turn them on, this makes them unusable for an office environment. 6. Worse bluetooth range. Pros: 1. Better at connecting to bluetooth 2. Unfold/fold to turn off/on Overall they're not bad per se, but kind of a step down.

I was looking for a great-sounding pair of ANC headphones. I read many reviews before I made my decision to go with the Sennheiser Momentum 3s. I probably own too many pairs of headphones already, but I love listening to great audio so I consider them a good investment. Have everything from Beats to Bose to JBL etc. When I looked at these I was comparing them with some of the usual big hitters in ANC - Sony XM4s and Bose 700s. My #1 interest above all was audio quality. I use them mostly at home when working on my laptop. The best ANC or call quality wasn't my pure focus since I don't use them much for travel or business calls. So many of the reviews I read touted the Momentum 3s as superb sound quality and a great choice if you're looking for amazing sounding audio above all else. So I purchased these and let me say that I was not disappointed. These sound fantastic - crisp and well-balanced audio. Everything sounds so clean and yet powerful. I love them. I also really like the retro styling of these. I went with the Sandy White pair and they just look cool and classy. If you're looking for the best all-around or more concerned with ANC and battery life, then there may be slightly better options out there - but for what I was looking for and putting audio quality above all else, these are absolutely fantastic. I listen to many different genres of music and they all sound great on these. There is plenty of bass if that's what you're looking for but not overwhelming and not at the cost of losing any of the balance in the mids/highs. The graphic equalizer on the Sennheiser app is nice if you want to make some tweaks to the sound. Bottom line - if you're looking for a great sounding pair of high-quality headphones, these are an excellent choice!

No, these do not sound quite as good as a high quality wired set, but they sound very good considering they are wireless. If you are expecting the same just don't buy wireless. Battery life is very good and running them is not difficult. The app is pretty good with a very unique eq that takes some playing with to get right. I also use it in conjunction with my music player eq and they do very well together. These have great separation, good deep bass, and have the typical Sennheiser awesome mids and highs. Definitely a step above good for wireless.

*** I AM MOSTLY A PC USER which isn’t really apart of the target market for these things, but I was looking for something wireless and light because I travel around a lot with a computer and I hate wires. LACK OF PC software: I know Pc users often get gaming headsets and  they’re not the target, but having no software is frustrating. See next sectio SMART PAUSE: first let me say, I was ready to return these things. Every time I looked down to my paper when taking notes, it would turn the head set off, then when I looked back up, it would go back on. That’s smart pause. As I understand it, the feature serves to turn the headset off when you’ve dropped them to your shoulders or take them off, but  Once you break the headset in and it starts getting uncalibrated from putting it on difference surfaces, the pauses happen at even less deliberate movements of your head. Small tilts of the head would cause it to pause. I tried turning off smart pause on the iPhone app but after I closed the app the settings would never save when I connected to my pc and disconnected from phone Bluetooth . I almost gave up but after a software update, I was able to turn off smart pause permanently by toggling it off in the app! The noise cancelling on these headphones is extremely It’s hard to describe but it feels as though the noise cancelling completely mutes ambient noises without making you feel like you’re on completely silenced from everything going on around you. If the door bell rings or something, I usually can still hear it if the volume isn’t too high which is a feature I appreciate. That said, if you’re using them to block out all noise, like on an airplane or something, I’d prefer something a little stronger - but these are perfect for my usage. Range; I can still hear these things in my bathroom upstairs, surprisingly excellent Sound quality: very high for wireless, but I’m not much of an audiophile. Battery life: once you turn off smart pause( which is a must if you intend on moving your head at all while using these) it’s pretty bad. It’s been 2 months and I think I get 10 hours of battery on a full charge ? Maybe it’s the industry standard but I’m constantly needing to charge these. Build quality; feels great at first but even after a few months of use, I can tell the frames feels flimsy, I feel like it would snap immediately if I stepped on them or something. Looks good, but definitely cheap materials outside actual ear pad radius

Superb sound. Don't really care about noise cancellation (at home anyway, havin't tried them on a plane, for example). But....dammit...I sure get driven nuts with a couple of things. Connections......connects to my tv with zero problem...but no sound most of the time. Have to disconnect  and reconnect to get them to work. And I don't like the way they pause. Sometimes an inadvertant movement of the right earcup makes them pause....so I have to fuss with them to get them unpaused. Sure wish there was a way to just disable the pause feature in the app. That said...GREAT sound...I'd buy them again, even with the niggles.

I would give it 5 stars, except for one major design flaw: the metal hinges that bend when you fold the headphones are sharp, and it’s easy to pinch your skin. (So easy, in fact, that there’s a warning label in the box about it!) I’ve been very careful, but after a few months of owning the headphones and using them daily, I’ve pinched the skin on my hand twice, both times drawing blood. I have no idea why this design flaw needs to exist, considering that I had both of the previous versions of the Momentum headphones and never had this issue.

I had read a couple reviews complaining that the headphones can "pinch" your hand when you're unfolding them. I didn't realize it was so bad. The first time it happened, they actually drew blood! The second time it happened nearly did so as well. It hasn't happened a third time because I'm so careful now. The other thing, which I didn't see in any of the reviews I read, is that these headphones are just barely too heavy. While I've never had this problem with any headphones before, my neck actually hurts a little bit after wearing these for more than a couple of hours. Pros: the sound is fantastic, the app has an equalizer. It comes with an aux cable if you are bad about keeping it recharged. Charge cable is the same as my android phone. Battery life is really quite good though. Overall I sorely regret not getting Bose instead.

I upgraded from the previous version (2.0), that I owned for 4+ years, and I can still use them - the 2.0 I own can't charge anymore, because of the port that broken of too many uses (they were used almost every single day, for at least 8h). I upgraded to these, and I can tell that while in terms of ANC if wasn't upgraded that much, the sound does live up to expectations. The sound quality is really good, and you can listen to pretty much anything as if it was played in front of you (kinda exaggerating, of course there's better headphones, but good for the price). The ANC is not as good as it could have been - but the sound quality definitely makes it for me, as it's good enough with sounds (and the ANC) that it actually hides pretty anything else. On the battery side, it lasts for about 16h from my use which is more that enough (volume dependent), especially if you travel a lot. The USB-C/A port makes it very easy to charge everywhere, and if you're without charge within 10 minutes it gets you to about an hour of charge, which is incredible if it's a long trip. Microphone - perfect for casual use, people might notice you're talking through the headset but the sound is very clear All in all, a very solid headset! Something I learned: if you feel annoyed by the sound stopping when you do a specific movement, - feat not! Just disable the "Smart Pause" feature in the mobile app, and when re-enabling it, it'll allow you to calibrate it to yourself so it actually becomes smart, and it does work every well. If you have the 2.0 and it still works as expected, I don't think it's an upgrade (in terms of price - if you can afford it, go for it). In all other cases, go for it! There's also other nice-to-have features, which just makes the overall experience amazing.

Quality These headphones are high quality, no doubt. Leather and metal, nothing cheap about the build. I am rough on headphones, these will last you. Annoyances The 'smart' features are more of a hassle than a help, however. It is supposed to auto-pause and play when you take the headphones on and off. It will sometimes pause even though you didn't take the headphones off. More frustrating is the auto-switching. This can connect to 2 devices. When you start playing something on another device, it will automatically switch. Sometimes this works. Most of the time, you'll have to take the headphones off, close them, and open them to reset them. Or go on the device and manually switch it/disable Bluetooth on the device you don't want to hear. It's just a hassle really. I will be listening to something on my PC and then my phone gets an email, so the headphones switch over so I can hear the notification sound, but it won't switch back. Good The audio quality is great, as to be expected for the price. I will say, it's not as good as other headphones in this price range, the bass can sound overpowering with the Noise Cancelling on, and I love bass. But this bass isn't that clean, somewhat muddy. You can edit the EQ manually though, in the Smart Control app. Dont pay MSRP for these, not convinced they are worth it. But, I don't regret getting them. If you get used to the bugs with the smart features, these are simply nice Bluetooth headphones.

I really do like these headphones, but they don't like me. Kept on automatically pausing my music and disconnecting from my phone. Maybe because I wore glasses, idk. But our relationship came to an end due to inconsistency.  -also they need to have the option to turn off Bluetooth so you can plug into the phone via audio cable and know that your saving power.

These headphones, while visually pleasing and comfortable, miss the mark for me. * You cannot charge the headphones using a USB-C PD cable * "Transparency-mode" pauses the music and lets outside noise in, but you seemingly can't do both (maybe I did it wrong) * I was expecting warm reproduction of audio, but this bass-heavy monstrosity lacked mid-range punch and drowned out any hope of redemption with muddled and indecisive bass; vocals sound pretty damn good though so... /shrug * There is over a millimeter of play with the USB-C charge port in the headphone housing, so have fun returning your headphones to Sennheiser in a year after that falls apart and stops charging I was really hoping this was a step up from the original Momentum Wireless cans which I loved, but had to return twice due to charging ports and buttons failing over time. I jumped at the chance to own a pair of Momentum 3s with USB-C charging (oh, the future looks bright!) but I see Sennheiser is still cutting corners. Bummer :-/

These headphones have a sensor to detect when the headphones have been taken off called "smart pause". Which sounds great, except that if I'm eating food the headphones turn off. If I'm drinking water they turn off. If I lean back into a pillow, it turns off. This "feature" causes WAY more problems than it's worth. Six months in and I want to throw them out the window it's so annoying. I had the predecessor headphones that I was much happier with.

I've owned these headphones for nearly a year and love most of the features and overall quality/sound, but the Bluetooth connectivity has been a consistent pain to troubleshoot. In previous circumstances I was able to reestablish connectivity by following the help documents/app, but now they won't even go into pairing mode and I'm left with an expensive pair of wired headphones. I suspect there's an issue with the 3.5 mm headphone jack, when being unplugged, doesn't flip back to Bluetooth connectivity mode. I've reached out to Sennheiser support, but have yet to hear back. I'll be looking at different options and suggest others do the same. I'll update this review if Sennheiser support responds and a positive resolution is achieved.

After using these cans, it is hard to go back to any other headphones. The sony xm3's and the bose 700 offer better noise canceling when compared to the Sennheiser's. But no one is going to need such a high level of noise-canceling in regular use unless they are frequent flyers. The sound quality is where the Sennheiser's shine. They have heavy bass without compromising the mids and highs. It makes any kind of music fun and enjoyable. You will never be disappointed with this purchase. People who value sound quality and comfort should definitely have this as their number 1 priority. The comfort is super amazing. so soft and the real lambskin leather enables me to wear it for prolonged time periods. They are Sennheiser, you can't go wrong.

If you are looking for the best sound quality within this price range, this is the one. Sennheiser does not disappoint. But this headphone has been such a pain for online meetings as it has 1. frequent connectivity issue 2. unstable motion control. For #1, Bluetooth connection is often off with my Macbook (works fine with my phone though), which I experienced it several times a day. Aa for #2, if the headphone slides just a little bit from the "right" position or angle, it automatically mutes the microphone and it's extremely frustrating to turn it back on because sometimes I can't get that right angle over my head. Thus, for online meetings, I'm switching back to more reliable wireless earphone. I really do love the sound quality but unfortunately I won't use it as frequent as I thought I would.

When using these headphones with the blue tooth connection to a Sony A/V receiver the maximum volume is still too low for useful listening if you are doing anything besides sitting down. I use them while walking on a treadmill and even with the excellent noise-canceling these headphones have the volume is insufficient. My fix was to cut off the blue tooth and attach the headphones to the receiver with a 25-foot cable.

1. Sound quality. They have curve on which sound will change in a first several months. This is unusual long curve, my ATH-M50x passed through this process much faster - it took two to three weeks. First month they sounded with excessive sub-bas, but lacking the punch at the same time. Next couple months excessive sub-bas gone, but sound was a bit hot with to much high frequency for my taste and still lacks mid-bass. Finally after about 3 month they sounds perfectly. Sound with bluetooth connection is very good, with usb it even better - you can hear more details and wider soundstage. Overall this is no-brainer best sound quality-wise ANC headphones on the market right now. 2. ANC One thing I noticed, Momentum 3 has very weak passive isolation, leading me never use it's ambient mode. Active noise cancellation blocks high amount of low frequency, but not much else. If it has better passive isolation, I think they'll be much closer to ANC performance of Sony's 1000XM3. 3. Battery Only 17 hours, but it's enough for me.

Very good headphone for folks who know what music is supposed to sound like. Very comfortable to wear. It needs a better case though if you want to pack it — a hard shell, preferably. There may be better headphones for noise reduction (ANC), but, in some cases those vendors have sacrificed sound quality - I am thinking now of Sony which ruined their headphone when they went to the XM3. Their XM2 had been terrific!

The good:  The music quality is off the hook, noticeably better than similarly priced headphones that I bought a few years ago.  It really is THAT good. The bad:  1) they are effectively useless for phone calls.  Whenever I try I get yelled at by my friends “I can barely hear you!” 2) the battery drains when not in use.  Inevitably I forget to plug in, so they are frequently dead when I need them. The verdict:  If you want to rock out with killer sound, buy em.  If you want general use headphones, look elsewhere

Many other headphones come with the promise of gimmicks, all these features that really... at the end of the day you don't need. Do some of them make your life easier? Yes. But you don't need them. The only extra with real value is ANC but even that (at least for me) does not win out in importance over sound quality. With these headphones Sennheiser seems to have focused on one thing: beautiful sound. Do they have the best battery life? No, but they have plenty, I don't know anyone who listens to music for more than a couple hours anyway and as someone who's had some very long commutes, the battery life is fine. They also don't have all the cool software features of the Sony WH-1000XMH4 (and yes I did purchase the Sonys as well to try them) or the best of the best ANC. What makes these headphones worthy pf 5 stars is simply that they sound beautiful, absolutely beautiful. They recreate sound with amazing clarity and detail for wireless headphones, definitely a good step above the Sonys, so if you're anything like me and it really just comes down to the sound quality for you get these headphones.

I did a lot of looking around before I purchased these.  I spent a lot of time reading blogs and checking out youtube videos and did some physical shopping as well and I am very glad I purchased these. Beyond the way they look (which I love--they have the old school charm of the headphones plugged into stereos in the 70s and 80s) they sound great, integrate with my phone and other sources easily, and the absolute kicker for me is the transparency mode. I find that noise cancelling headphones often leave me with a headache--apparently some people like myself experience ANC as ear pain--for me transparency mode cures that and also keeps me safe while I'm walking in my neighborhood.

Everyone know how good these sound...but one major flaw is the bluetooth. Not blaming Sennheiser, since this is a general issue with bluetooth, but buyers should know. Even with bluetooth 5.0.  A- it often drop even at arm's length. B-. Lag, simply not suitable for gaming. Especially, online shooters like PUBG.  The smart pause--though nice most of the time- can be accidentaly truggered and can be annoying when you are just moving around.  ( reviewed with firmware 3.1.3)

I wanted to like these headphones, but both my initial order and my replacement pair arrived with defective hardware on the right side. The first pair was ~60% quieter on the left, and the second had loud static with active noise cancelling enabled. The app is next to useless and these particular ear pads grew uncomfortable for extended listening. I'd say 4.5 stars of "meets expectations" if it weren't for the quality control issues.

Accidentally clipped my finger when I was unfolding the headphone. Bluetooth priority is confusing. About the smart pause, it happened once that my iPhone started playing music instead of playing from the headphone for about 2 seconds. Not sure whether this related to iOS 13 or  not.

I bought these  hoping for a decent sounding headphones.  That, they delivered, but there are some issues w these. The human hair thin connector jack first died out on one channel.  Then the other channel - now worthless.  The three way switch to inject the sound isolation circuit now only flips to two of the selections.  Connection issues are prevalent.  As long as the headphones have been charged - no problems.  Just don't be 20' away OR turn your head too quickly.  I had a pair of IEMs from this company - sounded good - but the bluetooth connection was weak on those as well.  Bluetooth is like on version 5 right now.  There should be no bluetooth issues.  Decent sound fair to poor battery life and the overall cheapness of the plastic/switches leads me to not recommend these.  Especially since there are many other headphones for the same amount of money.

5/5 Sound quality when wireless. When I plugged in for wired sound expecting to be blown away, the output was only occurring in one ear. No matter... I plan on using these wirless 95% of the time 3/5 Noise Cancellation. Being generous with this grade. I love how their are three settings (4 if you include transparent hearing), but the settings differ from "is noise cancellation on? (Low)" to "ah! I think it is on. (Medium/"Wind setting?")" to "I guess it is on.. but ill just turn the volume up. (Max)" 1/5 Accessories: Well they included the charger... but not the usb-c block. When using other companies blocks, such as apple, I have heard but not experienced that there have been issues. The headphone cord simply does not work. The carrying case will carry your headphones but by no means protect. Design is great and why I am not giving this 2 stars. But a lot of issues with this product. Only reason why I have not returned them yet is because I ordered a different pair of headphones and waiting for them to be delivered.

Amazing sound, great for pop and metal Updates: My subjective opinions: After one week of serious listening on these, the bass sounds too much. The headband adjuster is loose and I need to adjust them constantly. The earcup is just a little bit too small for me (I have big head and ears) but it shouldn't be a problem for most of the people. Overall, this headphone is probably the best choice for noise cancelling headphone. Before purchase, you should consider if you really need noise cancelling - if not, there are many, many better choices.

My old Momentums died out on me so it was time for an upgrade. The sounds on this is stellar, i enjoy the small equalizer you get in the downloadable app. I tested out the noise cancellation and it does a pretty good job, im not disappointed in any way! Other than me having a small head so i have to break them in so they dont squeeze my head too hard! I look forward to playing games with these one too. Worth the money

Awesome set of headphones. Moving from Studio Beats to these was such an improvement. Sound quality is very good. The noise canceling is really good as well. Feel really nice on the head. The build quality is top notch. Just wish the ear cups were made of cloth instead of the leatherette. Kind of pricey but well worth the upgrade. You will not be disappointed.
Not a audiophile guy but it does sound like Sony's WHXM3 which provides similar sound quality but better ANC. The lows are really heavy and ruin the mids and highs.

When I turn my head to the side headphones think I’m taking them off, pausing audio. That’s mildly annoying. When multiple devices are connected, headphones have a mind of their own on what should be played and where. I’ve messed with this a lot and it is very squirrelly. You can pause your music turn on a YouTube video, and it will mute the youtube video and resume your music on the other device (not through headphones). OR you have to figure out which app is the preferred app at the time on which device, otherwise your music/video will auto pause over and over until you disconnect all your devices and only have one source of audio on one device. You cannot play music in the background while on a call. I cannot stress enough how annoying this is 6 MONTHS into owning the headphones. The sound quality, is excellent. They are comfortable for a long time, and the battery life/noise canceling are fine. If they can fix the "smart" software these headphones will be excellent. As it stands I wouldn't recommend these to anyone.

I purchased an open box pair of headphones which were in pristine condition for $250 US dollars. Unlike most YouTube reviews of these headphones I found the carrying case to be great, and water proof/resistant judging by its zipper. Great sounding cans, modern Tech with Bluetooth 5.0 and a super solid construction. Metal headband with sheepskin leader.

Used these for listening to music and watching television.  In theory they were supposed to be able to pair to 2 devices.  Sometimes they would and other times not.  The final straw was when I wanted to use them on my phone and they wouldn't unpair with the TV.  At that point in time I was beyond the return time on Amazon so I put them in the trash.

these were an upgrade to my vmoda lp. at first i was considering buying another headset from vmoda but since it would have costed me around 400 dollars anyway i decided to look around the market at the 400 dollar price range. after much research i found these to be the best at the price range and bought them. after about 2+ months using them i can say for a fact that this is the best headphones i have owned, the quality is top notch, premium materials, and physical buttons. the sound quality after tuning it to my ears  it is superb. i have no complaints at all

I've been shopping around for a great pair of noise cancelling headphones for a few months now. I have been working from home and now I am preparing to take the bar, but I have a roommate who also works from home. Our desks are 10 feet apart and now, when I'm studying with these on, I can't hear her at all. The options and sensitivity of these are A1 and far surpass the need I had for them.

If like myself, you just care about audio quality this is the choice for you! The noise cancelling is decent but not perfect, also there is some static noises that can be heard at certain times. Battery life is also decent. I dont know if this is a common issue but there seems to be an issue with the sensors on the ear muffs which put calls on mute when i haven't moved them away from my ears at all. All in all minor complaints on an otherwise good product

The new bass king.  Deeper and more quantity of bass than any other headphones Ive heard including the bass cannons JVC SZ2000.  It's a Sennheiser.  You wont be disappointed.  If it doesn't rattle every single neuron in your brain, then you can return it.  It wont leave a single one left out.

Sound is the best I have heard coming from noise cancelling headphones The noise cancelling is top notch and they are comfortable enough to a point where I can listen to these for hours at a time. Build quality, materials are also up there. Way better fit and sound than my previous pair of Sennheiser PXC 550. I give it 4 out of 5 only because there is a pinch issue when you unfold the ear cups that grabs the skin on your hand between your thumb and index finger. Doesn't happen all the time but you'll notice it when it does.

There is a slight static noise with the Vocals of singers at higher volumes out of the box.But if you adjust the EQ with the Smart Control app just a tiny hair,it goes away.So it must have something to do with the sound digitalizer or whatever it's called.But besides that these sound amazing.
